awd_titl_txt: Young children's beliefs about causal systems: Learning about belief revision in the lab and in museums
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the most important processes in scientific thinking is belief revision: the ability to change an initial hypothesis in light of new evidence. In order to do this, children must be able to do two things. First, they must be able to reason about how the world works so that they can understand the causal systems they encounter, such as what causes earthquakes. Second, children must be able to think about their own knowledge and the process of learning so that they will know whether and how to change their beliefs about causal systems. This project seeks to (1) discover how the capacity for belief revision develops in the early elementary-school years, (2) explore how this capacity relates to children's awareness of their own learning, and (3) describe how both of these processes relate to children's interactions with museum exhibits. The research team involves developmental laboratories at the University of Pennsylvania and Brown University and informal STEM learning partners at the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia and the Providence Children's Museum. The project is funded by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program which funds fundamental research that seeks to understand, build theory to explain, and suggest interventions (and innovations) to address persistent challenges in STEM interest, education, learning, and participation.

The project involves two lines of research, which study children's responses to different kinds of science puzzles. The first series of experiments are lab-based and vary the information that children observe and the types of exploratory actions that they can take. Children are also interviewed to find out how they think about science and learning. This design is intended to determine how different sets of evidence and different exploratory actions affect children's learning. It also addresses how children's abilities for belief revision may differ between abstract and contextualized causal systems. This line of work additionally investigates when children gain the capacity to revise their beliefs explicitly in the face of counterevidence, linking their scientific thinking capacities to their developing metacognitive abilities. The second series of experiments observes and records children's explorations of and interactions in museum exhibits. Parents and children are interviewed and asked to comment on video clips of their museum explorations. This allows the researchers to examine how naturally occurring behavior in informal learning settings affects children's learning and views about learning. Findings can illuminate how children learn to integrate evidence with their beliefs, which can inform educational policies and practices around the teaching of science. These studies can also advance researchers and museum practitioners' understanding of how museum environments foster children's growth into healthy, independent thinkers and how to support caregivers' efforts to assist children's learning.

por.por_cntn:
Overview. A crucially important process in scientific thinking is belief revision: the ability to change an initial hypothesis in light of new evidence. This project seeks to (1) discover how the capacity for belief revision develops in preschool and early elementary school, (2) explore how this capacity relates to children's awareness of their own learning, and (3) describe how both of these processes relate to children's interactions and learning in informal learning environments (particularly, children’s museums). Although prior work has found that young children can implicitly revise their beliefs, this project uniquely aims to investigate how this process looks when it is brought into explicit awareness. As such, our work explores new aspects of the development of this important reasoning capacity, which can be used to inform approaches in formal and informal education.

 

Intellectual Merit. We conducted two broad lines of studies. The first line, based in the laboratory, examined how children’s belief revision develops, when children develop the capacity to revise their beliefs explicitly in the face of counterevidence, and how they revise their beliefs given their own exploration of a causal system. The overall focus of these studies was to chart the interplay between the type and strength of children’s initial beliefs and the type and strength of counterevidence they encounter in the belief revision process. We found that including more realistic scientific information in a causal reasoning task made it harder for children to respond correctly. Additionally, we found that children can spontaneously design unconfounded interventions to learn about a new causal system and can update their beliefs based on the evidence that they observe from these interventions. However, their actions on this system are heavily influenced by what they do first: Actions that lead to effects encourage children to keep seeking effects rather than seeking to discover the system’s underlying causal structure. Finally, children across preschool and early elementary school can revise their beliefs when given explicit verbal information that this belief is incorrect. They have more trouble doing so when merely observing counterevidence that is not verbally interpreted for them.

 

The second line of research was based in two museums: Providence Children’s Museum and the Academy of Natural Sciences in Philadelphia. This work examined how children engage in belief revision and reflect on their own process of belief revision during their naturalistic exploration of these informal learning environments. These studies involved children wearing video cameras to record their first-person perspective on their interaction with the museum exhibits. Children were then asked to reflect on that first-person perspective and to articulate their concepts of learning. The overall focus of these studies was to document the extent to which children’s exploratory behavior and their metacognitive understanding of this behavior relates to their developing abilities to revise their beliefs. We are finding that children engage more with interactive than static exhibits, and also that children spend more time at interactive exhibits when they set their own goals rather than following a museum-suggested goal. In addition, aspects of children’s museum experience relate to their metacognitive reflections on learning: Children were more likely to report that they would learn about a new toy by playing with it themselves when they had visited a children’s museum than when they had visited a natural history museum, suggesting that active exploratory experiences have an important role to play in shaping children’s approaches to their own learning.

 

Broader Impacts. These two lines of work are united by their focus on how children coordinate existing beliefs with new evidence, whether those beliefs are created by their current exploration or encouraged by the design of the study. As such, our findings can illuminate how children learn to integrate evidence with their beliefs, which can inform educational policies and practices around the teaching of science. Specifically, our findings highlight the importance of active exploration in the development of children’s scientific thinking abilities. This grant has provided the opportunity to deepen partnerships between researchers and museum practitioners in order to conduct these studies and disseminate their results, allowing this work to advance our understanding of how museum environments foster children's growth into healthy, independent thinkers and how to support caregivers' efforts to support children's learning and development.
